Chief Complaint: [**2177-4-30**]
   - around noon developed increased bleeding around trach and also slow
   pooling in post OP. ENT called and pt sedated/transiently paralyzed
   with propofol/vecuronium and put back on vent for ENT packing of mouth.
   - Rad onc consult called as family now wished to transfer all medical
   care to [**Hospital1 19**], plan to start radiation at 10am on [**5-1**] if stable to go
   to [**Hospital Ward Name **]
   - spoke to bed facilitator to get pt transfered to [**Hospital Unit Name 1**]
   - rad onc requesting onc data from Dr. [**First Name4 (NamePattern1) **] [**Last Name (NamePattern1) 2760**] ([**Telephone/Fax (1) 7396**].
   Spoke to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2760**]. Per Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2760**], he has terrible performance
   status, and recommmended that we get medical onc to see him. He
   suggested weekly erbitux (Ab to EGF receptor)
   - OSH pathology [**Hospital3 1959**] Hosp medical records [**Telephone/Fax (1) 4103**] to be
   faxed to us today.
   - transfused 2UPRBCs
   - IR placed IVF filter and coiled branches of inferior thyroid artery
   - family meeting: if rebleeds would want ENT surgery with resection

 AIRWAY, INABILITY TO PROTECT (RISK FOR ASPIRATION, ALTERED GAG,
   AIRWAY CLEARANCE, COUGH)
 HEMOPTYSIS
   67-yo man w/ SCC of the larynx s/p coil embolization of right inferior
   thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed [**3-/2177**], s/p trache and PEG
   [**3-/2177**], admitted for right LE DVT, now w/ significant bleeding from
   trache site.
   .
   #. Bleeding from trache site - Initially stable upon arrival to ICU;
   however, on hosp day 2, developed slow, persistant bleeding around
   trachea and welling into post. oralpharynx.
   - s/p ENT packing as well as neuro IR coiling of inf thyroid artery
   - if rebleeds, family would want aggressive ENT surgery
   - plan for XRT today on [**Hospital Ward Name **]
   - appreciate ENT
   - appreciate rad onc
   - follow-up oncology recs regarding any additional chemo
   - maintain active T&S
   - no anticoagulation
   .
   #. RLE DVT - DVT on OSH right LENI, no si/sx of PE or HD instability.
   Not an anticoagulation candidate given recent bleeding. Likely [**1-27**]
   decreased mobility at rehab and malignancy.
   - no anticoagulation given recent bleed
   - s/p IVC filter placement
   - monitor for HD instability, SOB, hypoxia given potential for PE
   .
   # Leukocytosis: New in setting of events yesterday. He has not spike a
   temp in 24 hrs, and no obvious localizing source. Given bleeding into
   OP and possibly airways yesterday, there is concern for
   pneumonitis/recurrent aspiration pna
   - resend sputum cx
   - f/u CXR this AM
   - add on diff
   - blood, urine cx
   - if spikes, would start Vanc/Zosyn for broad coverage
   .
   #. Aspiration PNA - Pt has h/o aspiration PNA, due to complete 10-day
   course of Ceftaz and Vanco today. Sputum cx here consistent with MSSA
   but has had MRSA in past. Now with new RLL infiltrate on CXRs this
   admission as well as elevated WBC.
   - re-send sputum culture
   - d/c all abx today as he will have completed a 10 day course
   - aspiration precautions
   - trache care
   - continue nebs
   .
   #. Laryngeal Ca - Complicated by recent right inferior thyroid artery
   bleed s/p coil embolization [**3-/2177**] by IR. S/p trache and PEG.
   - f/u onc and rad onc recs
   - percocet prn pain
   - Spoke to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2760**] in [**Hospital3 1959**]
   .
   #. Hypertension - Currently normo-tensive.
   - cont home lisinopril 40mg daily
   - consider adding additional agents if elevated
   .
   #. Anemia - Stable from recent baseline 25-28. Likely secodary to bleed
   and inflammation. Fe-studies suggest anemia of chronic disease.
   - continue to monitor, esp. in setting of bleeding
   - s/p 2U PRBC on [**4-30**]
   .
   #. Hyponatremia - Chronic, at baseline. Appears to be hypovolemic, but
   could consider contribution from SIADH. Serum and urine Osms pending.
   - f/u Osms-> c/w SIADH, so will fluid restrict
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #. COPD - No current complaints of SOB or dypnea, increased cough or
   change in sputum production.
   - continue home nebs
   .
   #. s/p CVA: No active issues. Not on ASA secondary to bleed.
   .
   #. FEN - NPO for procedure, IVF, replete lytes PRN
   #. PPx - SQ Heparin, H2B, bowel regimen
   #. Access - Rt PICC
   #. FULL CODE
   #. Dispo - ICU
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Comments: restart TF per peg today
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2177-4-30**] 04:22 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2177-4-30**] 02:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: SQ UF Heparin
   Stress ulcer: H2 blocker
   VAP: HOB elevation, Mouth care, Daily wake up, RSBI
   Comments:
   Communication: ICU consent signed Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition:ICU

Based on the progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the larynx, who underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed and tracheostomy and PEG placement. He was admitted to the ICU with a diagnosis of right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and is currently experiencing significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site.

The patient's current medical conditions include:

1. Bleeding from tracheostomy site: The patient developed slow and persistent bleeding around the trachea and pooling in the oral pharynx. He was sedated and paralyzed with propofol and vecuronium, and ENT packing was performed. If rebleeds occur, the family wishes to pursue aggressive ENT surgery.
2. Right lower extremity DVT: The patient has a DVT in the right lower extremity, which is not an anticoagulation candidate due to recent bleeding. An IVC filter was placed, and the patient is being monitored for signs of pulmonary embolism (PE) or hypoxia.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient has developed leukocytosis, which may be related to the recent bleeding and aspiration pneumonia (PNA). Sputum cultures and CXRs are pending to determine the cause of the PNA.
4. Aspiration PNA: The patient has a history of aspiration PNA and has completed a 10-day course of antibiotics. He is currently experiencing a new RLL infiltrate on CXRs and elevated WBC. Sputum cultures are pending, and aspiration precautions are being taken.
5. Laryngeal cancer: The patient has a diagnosis of laryngeal cancer, which is complicated by the recent right inferior thyroid artery bleed and tracheostomy.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is currently normotensive, but he is taking lisinopril 40mg daily. Additional agents may be added if blood pressure remains elevated.
7. Anemia: The patient has stable anemia, which is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation. He has received 2 units of packed red blood cells (PRBCs).
8. Hyponatremia: The patient has chronic hyponatremia, which may be related to hypovolemia or SIADH. Serum and urine osmolality are pending.
9. COPD: The patient has a history of COPD, but is not currently experiencing symptoms.
10. CVA: The patient has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA), but is not currently experiencing any active issues.

The patient's current medications include:

1. Propofol: 70 mcg/kg/min
2. Vecuronium: 1.5 mg/kg/hr
3. Heparin: 5,000 units SQ every 12 hours
4. Lorazepam: 1 mg IV every 2 hours as needed
5. Labetalol: 20 mg IV every 2 hours as needed
6. Ranitidine: 150 mg IV every 8 hours as needed
7. Lisinopril: 40 mg daily
8. Percocet: 5-10 mg every 4-6 hours as needed

The patient's current vital signs are:

1. Temperature: 36.6°C (97.9°F)
2. Heart rate: 87 beats per minute (bpm)
3. Blood pressure: 137/72 mmHg
4. Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
5. SpO2: 100%

The patient's current laboratory results are:

1. White blood cell count: 12.2 x 10^9/L
2. Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
3. Platelet count: 559 x 10^9/L
4. Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
5. Blood urea nitrogen: 27 mg/dL
6. Sodium: 130 mmol/L
7. Potassium: 4.5 mmol/L
8. Glucose: 112 mg/dL

The patient's current plan is to continue to monitor his bleeding and PNA, and to adjust his antibiotics and other medications as necessary. He will also be followed up with oncology and radiation oncology for further treatment recommendations.

   .

Based on the provided progress note, I summarize the patient's current condition and potential medical complications as follows:

**Current Condition:**

* The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, who has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleeding and tracheostomy with percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG).
* He is currently sedated and intubated, with a tracheostomy tube in place.
* He has developed significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which has been packed by ENT and treated with embolization of the superior and inferior thyroid arteries.
* He has a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter has been placed.
* He has leukocytosis, which is new and may be related to the recent events, including bleeding into the oropharynx and possible aspiration pneumonia.
* He has a history of aspiration pneumonia and has completed a 10-day course of antibiotics.
* He has hypertension, which is currently being managed with home lisinopril, and may require additional antihypertensive medication.
* He has anemia, which is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and is being monitored closely.
* He has hyponatremia, which is chronic and may be related to hypovolemia or SIADH.
* He has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is being managed with home nebulizers.
* He has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) and is not on aspirin due to the recent bleeding.

**Potential Medical Complications:**

* Rebleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could lead to respiratory distress and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Aspiration pneumonia, which could worsen the patient's respiratory status and increase the risk of respiratory failure.
* Pneumonitis, which could be caused by the recent bleeding and aspiration of oropharyngeal contents.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), which could be exacerbated by the patient's immobility and malignancy.
* Hypertensive crisis, which could worsen the patient's cardiac status and increase the risk of cardiac complications.
* Anemia and bleeding, which could lead to hypovolemic shock and potentially life-threatening complications.
* Hyponatremia, which could worsen the patient's electrolyte imbalance and increase the risk of seizures and other neurological complications.
* Respiratory failure, which could worsen the patient's respiratory status and increase the risk of cardiac complications.

**Assessment and Plan:**

* The patient's airway, breathing, and circulation (ABCs) should be closely monitored and managed to prevent respiratory distress and hypovolemic shock.
* The patient's bleeding should be closely monitored and managed to prevent rebleeding and worsening of anemia.
* The patient's respiratory status should be closely monitored and managed to prevent aspiration pneumonia and pneumonitis.
* The patient's electrolyte imbalance should be closely monitored and managed to prevent hyponatremia and other electrolyte-related complications.
* The patient's cardiac status should be closely monitored and managed to prevent hypertensive crisis and cardiac complications.
* The patient's pain should be closely monitored and managed to prevent discomfort and worsening of respiratory status.
* The patient's antibiotic therapy should be adjusted to cover the possibility of aspiration pneumonia and other bacterial infections.
* The patient's anticoagulation therapy should be adjusted to prevent DVT and PE, while taking into account the patient's recent bleeding and IVC filter placement.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA), hyponatremia, and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the larynx. He was previously admitted for bleeding from the tracheostomy site and was found to have a deep vein thrombosis (DVT) in his right leg. He underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery and was transferred back to the hospital for filter placement.

The patient is currently in the ICU and is being treated for bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which was packed and coiled. He is also being treated for a DVT in his right leg, for which an IVC filter was placed. The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia (PNA) and is currently being treated with antibiotics.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.6°C (97.9°F)
* Heart rate: 87 beats per minute
* Blood pressure: 137/72 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 14 breaths per minute
* SpO2: 100%

The patient's physical examination is significant for:

* Sedated and chronically ill-appearing
* Tracheostomy tube in place
* Coarse rhonchorous breath sounds throughout
* 2+ edema on the right lower extremity (RLE) with erythema
* Trace edema on the left lower extremity (LLE)
* PICC line in place

The patient's laboratory results are significant for:

* Hemoglobin: 9.7 g/dL
* White blood cell count: 12.2 K/uL
* Platelet count: 559 K/uL
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.5 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.1 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 4.7 mg/dL
* Troponin: 0.5 mg/dL

The patient's diagnosis is:

* SCC of the larynx
* Bleeding from the tracheostomy site
* DVT in the right leg
* Aspiration PNA
* Hypertension
* Anemia
* Hyponatremia
* COPD

The patient's plan is:

* Continue antibiotics for aspiration PNA
* Repeat x-ray tomorrow
* Continue tracheostomy care
* Start clindamycin per ENT
* Transfer to [**Hospital Ward Name **] for radiation therapy
* Continue tube feeds once OK with rad onc
* Monitor for bleeding and adjust plan as needed

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Further bleeding from the tracheostomy site
* Development of pulmonary embolism (PE) or deep vein thrombosis (DVT)
* Aspiration pneumonia (PNA) or other respiratory complications
* Anemia or bleeding complications
* Hypertension or hypotension
* Hyponatremia or other electrolyte imbalances
* COPD exacerbation or other respiratory complications
* Infection or sepsis
* Cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or heart failure.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CVA, hyponatremia, and SCC of the larynx, who was admitted for right LE DVT. He underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed and was later transferred to rehab. However, he developed bleeding from the tracheostomy site and was transferred back to the hospital for filter placement and IR-guided embolization of the tumor. He was found to have DVT in his right leg and was treated with a filter. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, and his respiratory status is stable.

Potential medical complications:

1. Bleeding from the tracheostomy site: The patient has had significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which may recur if not properly managed. The plan is to keep the cuff inflated and to repeat x-rays to monitor for any signs of bleeding.
2. Respiratory failure: The patient is on invasive ventilation, and his respiratory status is stable. However, there is a risk of respiratory failure if his ventilation is not properly managed.
3. DVT and PE: The patient has a DVT in his right leg, which may increase the risk of pulmonary embolism (PE). The plan is to monitor for any signs of PE and to continue anticoagulation therapy.
4. Aspiration pneumonia: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and his current respiratory status may increase the risk of aspiration. The plan is to continue antibiotics and to monitor for any signs of aspiration.
5. Laryngeal cancer: The patient has laryngeal cancer, which may recur or progress if not properly managed. The plan is to follow up with radiation oncology and to monitor for any signs of recurrence.
6. Hypertension: The patient has hypertension, which may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications. The plan is to continue his current antihypertensive medication.
7. Anemia: The patient has anemia, which may increase the risk of bleeding and other complications. The plan is to monitor his anemia and to consider transfusions if necessary.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient has hyponatremia, which may increase the risk of seizures and other complications. The plan is to monitor his sodium levels and to consider fluid restriction if necessary.
9. COPD: The patient has COPD, which may increase the risk of respiratory failure and other complications. The plan is to continue his current bronchodilators and to monitor for any signs of worsening COPD.

Overall, the patient is at risk for several medical complications, including bleeding, respiratory failure, DVT and PE, aspiration pneumonia, laryngeal cancer, hypertension, anemia, hyponatremia, and COPD. The plan is to monitor these complications closely and to adjust his treatment as necessary to prevent or manage them.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of cervical artery dissection, hyponatremia, and squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the larynx. He has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleeding and has a tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG) tube in place.

The patient has had significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which has been packed and coiled. He has also developed a right leg deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and has been placed on a filter. The patient is currently receiving mechanical ventilation and has a chest x-ray showing patchy left lower lobe infiltrate and atelectasis, which has improved.

The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is being treated with antibiotics. He also has a history of SCC of the larynx and is scheduled for chemoradiation and teeth extraction as an outpatient.

The patient has several medical complications, including:

1. Bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which is currently being managed with packing and coiling.
2. Right leg DVT, which is being treated with a filter.
3. Aspiration pneumonia, which is being treated with antibiotics.
4. Hypopharyngeal bleeding, which is being managed with coil embolization.
5. Laryngeal cancer, which is being treated with chemoradiation and teeth extraction.
6. Hyponatremia, which is being monitored and managed with fluid restriction if necessary.
7. Anemia, which is being managed with iron studies and monitoring.
8. Hypertension, which is being managed with medication.
9. Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD), which is being managed with nebulizers.

The patient's plan includes:

1. Continuing antibiotics for aspiration pneumonia.
2. Monitoring and managing bleeding from the tracheostomy site.
3. Treating the right leg DVT with a filter.
4. Scheduling chemoradiation and teeth extraction for the patient's SCC of the larynx.
5. Monitoring and managing hyponatremia.
6. Managing anemia with iron studies and monitoring.
7. Managing hypertension with medication.
8. Continuing nebulizers for COPD.
9. Transferring the patient to a rehabilitation facility once his bleeding has stabilized.

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is to remain in the ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CVA, hyponatremia, and SCC of the larynx. He underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed and was admitted for right LE DVT. He had a significant bleeding episode from the tracheostomy site, which was packed and coiled. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation and has a chest x-ray showing patchy left LLL infiltrate and LLL atelectasis.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding from trache site: The patient is at risk of further bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could be life-threatening. Close monitoring and packing of the site is necessary to prevent bleeding.
2. Right LE DVT: The patient has a DVT in the right leg, which may lead to pulmonary embolism (PE) if not treated. Anticoagulation therapy is contraindicated due to recent bleeding, but an IR-guided IVC filter is in place.
3. Aspiration PNA: The patient has a history of aspiration PNA and is currently on antibiotics. The sputum culture shows MSSA, but the patient has had MRSA in the past. Close monitoring for signs of infection and adjustment of antibiotics as necessary are important.
4. Laryngeal Ca: The patient has a complex case of laryngeal cancer, complicated by recent bleeding from the right inferior thyroid artery. Close follow-up with hematology and oncology is necessary for chemoradiation and teeth extraction.
5. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension is currently well-controlled, but close monitoring is necessary to adjust medication as needed.
6. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation. Close monitoring and transfusion as necessary are important.
7. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is chronic and may be related to SIADH. Serum and urine osmolarities are pending, and fluid restriction may be necessary if SIADH is confirmed.
8. COPD: The patient has a history of COPD, but no current complaints of SOB or dyspnea. Close monitoring for signs of respiratory distress is necessary.
9. s/p CVA: The patient's CVA is stable, but close monitoring for signs of increased intracranial pressure or bleeding is necessary.

ICU Care:

* Nutrition: Tube feeds will be started once approved by radiation oncology.
* Glycemic control: Close monitoring of blood glucose levels is necessary to adjust medication as needed.
* Prophylaxis: DVT prophylaxis with a filter and HEP SQ, stress ulcer prophylaxis with Zantac, and VAP prophylaxis with a heat and moisture exchanger.
* Code status: Full code.
* Disposition: The patient will be transferred to a hospital ward for radiation therapy.

Based on the patient's progress note, I summarize the information as follows:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of SCC of the larynx, CVA, hyponatremia, and DVT. He was admitted to the ICU due to significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site. The patient has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed and has a tracheostomy and PEG in place.

The patient's current condition is as follows:

* Hemodynamic monitoring: Tension-free, with a heart rate of 87 bpm and a blood pressure of 137/72 mmHg.
* Respiratory support: Invasive ventilation with a tracheostomy tube, with a ventilation mode of CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow, and a PEEP of 5 cmH2O.
* Laboratory results: The patient has anemia, hyponatremia, and decreased platelet count.
* Imaging studies: The patient has a DVT on OSH right LENI, and a new infiltrate on CXRs this admission.

The patient's potential medical complications are:

* Bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which is suspected to be secondary to tumor.
* Development of pneumonia, given the patient's history of aspiration PNA and current sputum culture results.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and pulmonary embolism (PE), given the patient's history of DVT and decreased mobility at rehab.
* Hypertension, given the patient's history of hypertension and current blood pressure readings.
* Anemia, given the patient's current laboratory results and history of bleeding.
* Hyponatremia, given the patient's current laboratory results and history of chronic hyponatremia.
* COPD, given the patient's history of COPD and current respiratory support.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding from the tracheostomy site and adjust therapy as needed.
* Continue antibiotics for suspected aspiration PNA until the issue is resolved.
* Monitor for DVT and PE, and consider anticoagulation therapy if the patient is not an anticoagulation candidate.
* Continue to monitor the patient's laboratory results, including electrolytes, hemoglobin, and platelet count.
* Consider adding additional agents for hypertension if the patient's blood pressure remains elevated.
* Continue to monitor the patient's respiratory status, including oxygen saturation and ventilation requirements.
* Consider repeating imaging studies, including CXRs and US of the left lung, to evaluate for new processes.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of CVA, hyponatremia, and SCC of the larynx. He was admitted for right LE DVT and underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed. He had a tracheostomy and PEG placement, and was transferred to the ICU for filter placement due to a rebleed. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation and has been treated with antibiotics for suspected aspiration PNA.

The patient has multiple medical complications, including:

* Bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which has been packed and coiled, and will require further management by ENT and possibly radiation therapy.
* Right LE DVT, which is not an anticoagulation candidate due to recent bleeding.
* Aspiration PNA, which is being treated with antibiotics and will require further management.
* Laryngeal cancer, which is complicated by recent right inferior thyroid artery bleed and will require further management.
* Hypertension, which is currently well-controlled.
* Anemia, which is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation.
* Hyponatremia, which is chronic and may be contributing to hypovolemia or SIADH.
* COPD, which is not currently active.

Potential medical complications that can arise:

* Continued bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could lead to respiratory distress and further complications.
* Development of pulmonary embolism or deep vein thrombosis due to the patient's immobility and malignancy.
* Infection or sepsis due to the patient's compromised immune system and recent procedures.
* Further complications from the patient's anemia, such as cardiovascular instability or decreased oxygen delivery to tissues.
* Development of acute kidney injury or chronic kidney disease due to the patient's hyponatremia and potential hypovolemia.
* Respiratory failure or distress due to the patient's COPD or aspiration PNA.
* Cardiovascular instability or arrhythmias due to the patient's hypertension or anemia.
* Neurological complications due to the patient's CVA or recent bleeding.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Further management of the bleeding from the tracheostomy site by ENT and possibly radiation therapy.
* Anticoagulation therapy for the DVT, pending further evaluation.
* Antibiotics for the aspiration PNA, with possible change in antibiotic regimen based on culture results.
* Further management of the patient's laryngeal cancer, including chemoradiation and teeth extraction.
* Monitoring of the patient's hypertension, anemia, and hyponatremia, with possible adjustments to therapy as needed.
* Further evaluation and management of the patient's COPD and respiratory status.
* Monitoring of the patient's neurological status and cardiovascular stability.
* Transfer to a hospital ward for radiation therapy and further management of the patient's condition.

Based on the provided progress note, here is a summary of the patient's health progress in the ICU:

The patient is a critically ill individual who was admitted to the ICU with a 24-hour history of invasive ventilation, angiography, and multiple antibiotic infusions. The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.6°C, heart rate of 87 beats per minute, blood pressure of 137/72 mmHg, respiratory rate of 14 breaths per minute, and oxygen saturation of 100%. The patient is receiving mechanical ventilation with a tidal volume of 500 mL, respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute, and a fraction of inspired oxygen (FiO2) of 40%.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.2 x 10^9/L, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 559 x 10^9/L. The patient's blood chemistry results show a creatinine level of 0.5 mg/dL, blood urea nitrogen (BUN) level of 27.8 mg/dL, and glucose level of 112 mg/dL.

The patient's medical history is significant for an unknown allergy to penicillins, and the patient has received multiple antibiotics, including ceftazidime, vancomycin, and cefipime. The patient is also receiving prophylactic anticoagulation with heparin sodium and antacid with ranitidine.

Potential medical complications that may arise from the patient's condition include:

1. Respiratory failure: The patient's need for invasive ventilation and mechanical ventilation may increase the risk of respiratory failure, particularly if the patient's lung function deteriorates or if there is a complication such as pneumonia.
2. Sepsis: The patient's multiple antibiotic infusions and recent invasive procedures may increase the risk of sepsis, particularly if the patient's immune system is compromised.
3. Bleeding: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and recent invasive procedures may increase the risk of bleeding, particularly if the patient's platelet count is low or if there is a coagulopathy.
4. Renal failure: The patient's elevated BUN level and creatinine level may indicate renal failure or impairment, particularly if the patient's fluid balance is not carefully monitored.
5. Nutritional deficiencies: The patient's prolonged stay in the ICU may increase the risk of nutritional deficiencies, particularly if the patient is not receiving adequate nutrition through enteral or parenteral means.
6. Gastrointestinal complications: The patient's antacid therapy and recent invasive procedures may increase the risk of gastrointestinal complications, such as nausea, vomiting, or constipation.
7. Cardiovascular complications: The patient's anticoagulation therapy and recent invasive procedures may increase the risk of cardiovascular complications, such as arrhythmias or cardiac arrest.

Overall, the patient's condition is complex and requires close monitoring and careful management to prevent potential complications and promote recovery.

 ENT plans to remove packing

   - follow-up Oncology recs regarding additional chemo (? Cisplatin), to

        - stopped current Abx (Vanc / Zosyn) [**4-30**] as not needed anymore
        - start Clindamycin for ENT coverage, clarify need and length w/
   ENT
   .

   protection in the setting of refractory bleeding around trach site.
   Decrease Fi02 tonight given most recent ABG with Pa02 124, repeat at
   11pm.  Keep ventilated overnight and tomorrow while packing removed and
   for next rad onc session. Re-eval bleeding prior to consideration of
   extubation.
   .

   Not an anticoagulation candidate given recent bleeding. Likely [**1-27**]
   decreased mobility at rehab and malignancy.  Had IVC filter placed
   [**2177-4-30**].  No si/sx to raise concern for PE.
   - no anticoagulation given recent bleed, s/p IVC filter placement
   .

   OP and possibly airways yesterday, there is concern for
   pneumonitis/recurrent aspiration pna. Sputum Cx re-sent. CXR improved

   - f/u sputum cx data
   - send blood, urine cx as well

   .

   course of Ceftaz and Vanco today. Sputum cx here consistent with MSSA
   but has had MRSA in past. Now with new RLL infiltrate on CXRs this
   admission as well as elevated WBC.
   - f/u sputum culture
   - d/c
d today as he has completed a 10 day course

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, who has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for a hypopharyngeal bleed, and has been admitted to the ICU for right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site.

The patient is currently mechanically ventilated due to refractory bleeding around the tracheostomy site, and is at risk for aspiration and altered gag reflex. The patient's airway is being closely monitored, and the plan is to continue mechanical ventilation overnight and the next day while the packing is removed and for the next radiation oncology session.

The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and there is concern for recurrent aspiration pneumonia due to the bleeding into the oropharynx and possibly the airways. The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, and there is a concern for pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia. Sputum cultures are pending, and the patient is being treated with antibiotics for coverage.

The patient has also been diagnosed with anemia, likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and is being monitored closely. The patient has a history of hypertension, and the plan is to continue home lisinopril and consider adding a beta blocker as needed.

The patient has a history of chronic hyponatremia, which appears to be hypovolemic, but could also be contributed to by SIADH. Serum and urine osmolality tests are pending, and the patient will be fluid-restricted if SIADH is confirmed.

The patient has a history of COPD, but is currently not experiencing symptoms. The patient is being treated with home nebulizers.

The patient has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) and is not on aspirin secondary to the bleed.

The patient's medications include propofol, ranitidine, and heparin sodium for prophylaxis, and clindamycin for coverage.

The patient's vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C, heart rate of 84 beats per minute, and blood pressure of 131/70 mmHg. The patient's oxygen saturation is 100%, and the patient is receiving supplemental oxygen through a tracheostomy tube.

The patient's laboratory results show a white blood cell count of 12.2, hemoglobin of 9.7 g/dL, and platelet count of 559. The patient's electrolyte levels are within normal limits, with the exception of hyponatremia.

The patient's radiology results show a right lower extremity DVT, and a new infiltrate on the chest X-ray.

The patient's plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, antibiotics for coverage, and close monitoring of the bleeding and airway. The patient will also be re-evaluated for extubation after the next radiation oncology session.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following information can be summarized:

The patient is a mechanically ventilated ICU patient who underwent angiography 24 hours prior. They have been receiving various medications, including antibiotics, anticoagulants, and anti-inflammatory agents. Their vital signs are stable, with a temperature of 36.7°C (98°F), heart rate of 84 bpm, and blood pressure of 131/70 mmHg. They are receiving supplemental oxygen and have a tracheostomy tube in place.

The patient's laboratory results show mild anemia (Hct 25.6%), thrombocytopenia (Plt 559), and elevated lactate (TCO2 31). Their blood glucose level is within normal range (112 mg/dL). Other lab results, including complete blood count, electrolytes, and renal function tests, are within normal limits.

The patient's physical examination is limited due to their intubation and mechanical ventilation. However, they are able to respond to stimuli and have a normal heart rhythm.

The patient's medical complications and potential risks include:

1. Aspiration risk due to inability to protect their airway
2. Hemoptysis, which may be related to their underlying condition or a complication of angiography
3. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and stress ulcer due to prolonged bed rest and mechanical ventilation
4. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP) and respiratory failure due to prolonged mechanical ventilation
5. Hemodynamic instability due to hypovolemia or bleeding
6. Worsening of underlying medical conditions, such as sepsis or multi-organ failure

The patient's plan includes continued mechanical ventilation, antibiotics, and anticoagulation therapy. They will also require close monitoring of their vital signs, laboratory results, and physical examination.

   67-yo man w/ SCC of the larynx s/p coil embolization of right inferior
   thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleed [**3-/2177**], s/p trache and PEG
   [**3-/2177**], admitted for right LE DVT, now w/ significant bleeding from
   trache site.
   .
   #. Bleeding from trach site - Initially stable upon arrival to ICU;
   however, on hosp day 2, developed slow, persistant bleeding around
   trachea and into posterior oropharynx. Packed by ENT and now s/p
   embolization of sup/inf thyroid artery by neuron IR. Hct currently
   stable.
   - if rebleeds, family would want aggressive ENT surgery
   - s/p mapping and first session XRT today, to continue tomorrow.
   - appreciate ENT, Rad-Onc involvement
 ENT plans to remove packing
   tomorrow.  Med onc wants dental work and CT head and neck, hold off on
   CT today given recent dye load in IR.  Readdress in 24-48 hours after
   monitoring creatinine.
   - follow-up Oncology recs regarding additional chemo (? Cisplatin), to
   be started as outpatient.
   - maintain active T&S
   - no anticoagulation
   - will need antibiotics per ENT for coverage:
        - stopped current Abx (Vanc / Zosyn) [**4-30**] as not needed anymore
        - start Clindamycin for ENT coverage, clarify need and length w/
   ENT
   .
   # Mechanically ventilated:  Placed on ventilator for further airway
   protection in the setting of refractory bleeding around trach site.
   Decrease Fi02 tonight given most recent ABG with Pa02 124, repeat at
   11pm.  Keep ventilated overnight and tomorrow while packing removed and
   for next rad onc session. Re-eval bleeding prior to consideration of
   extubation.
   .
   #. RLE DVT - DVT on OSH right LENI, no si/sx of PE or HD instability.
   Not an anticoagulation candidate given recent bleeding. Likely [**1-27**]
   decreased mobility at rehab and malignancy.  Had IVC filter placed
   [**2177-4-30**].  No si/sx to raise concern for PE.
   - no anticoagulation given recent bleed, s/p IVC filter placement
   .
   # Leukocytosis: New in setting of events yesterday. He has not spike a
   temp in 24 hrs, and no obvious localizing source. Given bleeding into
   OP and possibly airways yesterday, there is concern for
   pneumonitis/recurrent aspiration pna. Sputum Cx re-sent. CXR improved
   today AM. Diff w/ 86% PMNs.
   - f/u sputum cx data
   - send blood, urine cx as well
   - stopped Vanc / Zosyn, start Clinda as above for ENT coverage
   .
   #. Aspiration PNA - Pt has h/o aspiration PNA, due to complete 10-day
   course of Ceftaz and Vanco today. Sputum cx here consistent with MSSA
   but has had MRSA in past. Now with new RLL infiltrate on CXRs this
   admission as well as elevated WBC.
   - f/u sputum culture
   - d/c
d today as he has completed a 10 day course
   - cont aspiration precautions, trache care, nebulizers
   .
   #. Laryngeal Ca - Complicated by recent right inferior thyroid artery
   bleed s/p coil embolization [**3-/2177**] by IR. S/p trache and PEG.
   - f/u onc and rad onc recs as above
   - Green team spoke to Dr. [**Last Name (STitle) 2760**] in [**Hospital3 1959**]
   .
   #. Hypertension - Currently normo-tensive, was hypertensive yesterday.
   Per ENT, needs improved control w/ SBP 120s.
   - cont home lisinopril 40mg daily
   - consider adding BB as needed (prefer IV Labetalol)
   .
   #. Anemia - Stable from recent baseline 25-28. Likely secodary to bleed
   and inflammation. Fe-studies suggest anemia of chronic disease.
   - continue to monitor closely, esp. in setting of bleeding
   - s/p 2U PRBC on [**4-30**]
   .
   #. Hyponatremia - Chronic, at baseline. Appears to be hypovolemic, but
   could consider contribution from SIADH. Serum and urine Osms pending.
   - f/u Osms-> c/w SIADH, so will fluid restrict
   - continue to monitor
   .
   #. COPD - No current complaints of SOB or dypnea, increased cough or
   change in sputum production.
   - continue home nebs
   .
   #. s/p CVA: No active issues. Not on ASA secondary to bleed.
   ICU Care
   Nutrition:
   Nutren Pulmonary (Full) - [**2177-5-2**] 02:00 AM 20 mL/hour
   Glycemic Control:
   Lines:
   PICC Line - [**2177-4-30**] 04:22 AM
   18 Gauge - [**2177-4-30**] 02:00 PM
   Prophylaxis:
   DVT: IVC filter, Hep SC, pneumobotts
   Stress ulcer: H2B
   VAP:  Bundle
   Comments:
   Communication:  Comments:
   Code status: Full code
   Disposition: ICU

Based on the patient's progress note, the following potential medical complications can arise:

1. Bleeding from trache site: The patient is experiencing persistent bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which may require further embolization or surgical intervention.
2. Aspiration PNA: The patient has a history of aspiration PNA and has developed a new RLL infiltrate on CXRs, which may indicate a recurrence of aspiration pneumonia.
3. Leukocytosis: The patient's white blood cell count is elevated, which may indicate an infection or inflammation.
4. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is currently controlled, but may require further management to prevent complications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and may require further transfusions or iron supplementation.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is chronic, but may require fluid restriction and close monitoring to prevent complications.
7. Respiratory failure: The patient is mechanically ventilated and may require further support to manage his respiratory failure.
8. DVT: The patient has a right LE DVT, which may require further anticoagulation therapy or surgical intervention.
9. Pneumonitis: The patient's symptoms and laboratory results suggest the possibility of pneumonitis, which may require further evaluation and treatment.

Based on these potential complications, the patient's plan of care should include:

1. Close monitoring of bleeding from the tracheostomy site and aspiration PNA.
2. Further evaluation and treatment of leukocytosis, including blood and urine cultures.
3. Management of hypertension, anemia, and hyponatremia.
4. Continued respiratory support and close monitoring for respiratory failure.
5. Further evaluation and treatment of DVT and potential PE.
6. Evaluation and treatment of pneumonitis, including antibiotics and corticosteroids.
7. Close monitoring of the patient's overall condition and adjustment of his plan of care as needed.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man who has been admitted to the ICU for a hypopharyngeal bleed and is currently receiving mechanical ventilation for airway protection. He has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery and has a history of squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx.

The patient has developed bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which was initially stable but has now persisted and required embolization of the suprarenal and inferior thyroid arteries. The bleeding has been controlled, and the patient's hemoglobin level is currently stable.

The patient has a history of right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and has undergone placement of an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter. He is not an anticoagulation candidate due to the recent bleeding.

The patient has leukocytosis, which is new and may be related to the recent events. He has not had a fever in the past 24 hours and has no obvious localizing source of infection. There is concern for pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia, and sputum cultures have been sent.

The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and has completed a 10-day course of antibiotics. He has a new right lower lobe infiltrate on chest X-ray and elevated white blood cell count.

The patient has anemia, which is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation. He has received 2 units of packed red blood cells and will continue to be monitored closely.

The patient has hyponatremia, which is chronic and may be related to hypovolemia or SIADH. Serum and urine osmolality levels are pending.

The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) and is receiving home nebulizers.

The patient has a history of cerebrovascular accident (CVA) and is not on aspirin due to the recent bleeding.

Potential medical complications that may arise include:

1. Continued bleeding from the tracheostomy site or other areas.
2. Pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia.
3. Development of sepsis or septic shock.
4. Progression of the DVT to pulmonary embolism (PE).
5. Anemia or bleeding due to the patient's underlying medical conditions.
6. Hyponatremia or SIADH.
7. COPD exacerbation.
8. CVA or stroke.

Based on the patient's current condition and medical history, it is essential to continue close monitoring and management of his bleeding, respiratory status, and other underlying medical conditions to prevent potential complications and ensure his overall well-being.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with a history of squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx, who underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for a hypopharyngeal bleed. He was admitted to the ICU for a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and is currently mechanically ventilated due to refractory bleeding around the tracheostomy site. The patient has been experiencing bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which has been stabilized with embolization of the suprarenal and inferior thyroid arteries. He has also developed leukocytosis, likely secondary to the recent events, and is at risk for aspiration pneumonia.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for continued bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could lead to respiratory distress and cardiac complications.
2. Aspiration Pneumonia: The patient's history of aspiration pneumonia and recent bleeding into the oropharynx and possibly airways increase his risk for recurrent aspiration pneumonia.
3. Pneumonitis: The patient's leukocytosis and recent bleeding may indicate pneumonitis, which could lead to respiratory failure.
4. Hypertension: The patient's history of hypertension and recent elevation of blood pressure may require closer monitoring and potential adjustments to his antihypertensive medications.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia may be secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and may require further evaluation and treatment.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's chronic hyponatremia may be exacerbated by hypovolemia, and may require fluid restriction and close monitoring.
7. COPD: The patient's history of COPD may require continued management with nebulizers and close monitoring for any changes in his respiratory status.
8. DVT: The patient's right lower extremity DVT may require further evaluation and treatment, including anticoagulation therapy once the bleeding risk has decreased.

Recommendations:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding status and adjust his anticoagulation therapy accordingly.
2. Manage the patient's aspiration precautions and tracheostomy care to prevent further bleeding and aspiration.
3. Continue to monitor the patient's leukocytosis and consider further evaluation and treatment for pneumonitis or aspiration pneumonia.
4. Adjust the patient's antihypertensive medications as needed to maintain optimal blood pressure control.
5. Monitor the patient's anemia and consider further evaluation and treatment as necessary.
6. Continue to monitor the patient's hyponatremia and adjust his fluid management accordingly.
7. Continue to manage the patient's COPD with nebulizers and close monitoring.
8. Consider further evaluation and treatment for the patient's DVT, including anticoagulation therapy once the bleeding risk has decreased.

The patient was started on clindamycin for ENT coverage and will continue to receive radiation therapy to the head and neck for bleeding control.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding: The patient is at risk for continued bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which may require further intervention, including embolization or surgical exploration.
2. Pneumonia: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and is at risk for recurrent aspiration pneumonia due to his tracheostomy and recent bleeding.
3. Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for VAP due to his prolonged use of mechanical ventilation.
4. Deep vein thrombosis (DVT): The patient has a history of DVT and is at risk for further clot formation, particularly in the setting of immobility and malignancy.
5. Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is at risk for PE due to his DVT and recent immobilization.
6. Hypertension: The patient's blood pressure is not well-controlled, and he may require further medication to manage his hypertension.
7. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and he may require further transfusions or treatment to manage his anemia.
8. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia is likely secondary to hypovolemia, but may also be related to SIADH. He may require further treatment to manage his hyponatremia.
9. Laryngeal cancer: The patient's laryngeal cancer is complicated by his recent bleeding and may require further treatment, including radiation therapy or surgery.

Assessment and Plan:

The patient's bleeding has stabilized, but he remains at risk for further bleeding and complications. He will continue to receive radiation therapy to the head and neck for bleeding control and will be monitored closely for signs of bleeding or other complications. The patient will also require further treatment for his DVT, including anticoagulation therapy, and will be monitored for signs of PE. He will require further management of his hypertension, anemia, and hyponatremia.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old male with Supraglottic Cancer (SCCA) in the larynx, who has undergone radiation therapy (XRT) and has had significant pharyngeal bleeding. He has undergone initial mapping and tracheostomy with packing to control bleeding.

The patient's current condition is:

* Respiratory failure, requiring mechanical ventilation (CMV/ASSIST/AutoFlow mode) with a set tidal volume of 500 mL and respiratory rate of 12 breaths per minute.
* Hemothorax, with ongoing bleeding controlled by packing and transfusion of blood products.
* Deep vein thrombosis (DVT) treated with an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter.
* Nutritional support via tube feeds, with a goal of 20 mL/hour.

Potential medical complications that can arise from the patient's current condition include:

* Pneumonia or other respiratory infections due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and immunosuppression.
* Bleeding complications, including further hemothorax or hemoptysis, due to ongoing bleeding and potential coagulopathy.
* DVT or pulmonary embolism due to immobility and prolonged mechanical ventilation.
* Stress ulcers or gastrointestinal bleeding due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and immunosuppression.
* Infection, including ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP), due to prolonged mechanical ventilation and immobility.
* Metabolic complications, including hyperglycemia or hypoglycemia, due to altered glucose metabolism and potential insulin resistance.

The patient's plan of care includes:

* Weaning sedation and pressure support, with a goal of trial of spontaneous breathing when tolerated.
* Continuing to monitor for bleeding and coagulopathy, with repeat CT scans as needed.
* Maintaining nutritional support via tube feeds.
* Managing stress ulcers and gastrointestinal bleeding prophylactically.
* Monitoring for infection, including VAP, and treating promptly if identified.
* Maintaining glycemic control and monitoring for metabolic complications.

Close monitoring of the patient's condition and prompt treatment of any complications are essential to prevent further deterioration and improve outcomes.

   A 67 yo man w/ SCC of the larynx s/p coil embolization of right

   trache site.
   .
   #. Bleeding from trach site - Initially stable upon arrival to ICU;
   however, on hosp day 2, developed slow, persistant bleeding around
   trachea and into posterior oropharynx. Packed by ENT and now s/p
   embolization of sup/inf thyroid artery by neuron IR. Hct currently
   stable.  Patient was unpacked on [**2177-5-2**] with resolution of the
   bleeding.  We will hold off on getting a CT as recent radiation will
   increase artifact and it likely will not change treatment.
   - if rebleeds, family would want aggressive ENT surgery
   - Continue XRT to head/neck for bleeding control.
   - appreciate ENT, Rad-Onc involvement.
   - follow-up Oncology recs regarding additional chemo (? Cisplatin), to
   be started as outpatient.
   - maintain active T&S
   - no anticoagulation
   - will need antibiotics per ENT for coverage:
        - stopped current Abx (Vanc / Zosyn) [**4-30**] as not needed anymore
        - start Clindamycin for ENT coverage, clarify need and length w/
   ENT
   .
   # Mechanically ventilated:  Placed on ventilator for further airway
   protection in the setting of refractory bleeding around trach site.
   Decrease Fi02 tonight given most recent ABG with Pa02 124, repeat at
   11pm.  Keep ventilated overnight and tomorrow while packing removed and
   for next rad onc session. Re-eval bleeding prior to dropping cuff on
   trach.  If not actively bleeding may be able to drop cuff and use trach
   mask.
   -Trial of PS
 attempt to keep off vent.
   .
   #. RLE DVT - DVT on OSH right LENI, no si/sx of PE or HD instability.
   Not an anticoagulation candidate given recent bleeding. Likely [**1-27**]
   decreased mobility at rehab and malignancy.  Had IVC filter placed
   [**2177-4-30**].  No si/sx to raise concern for PE.

   temp in 24 hrs, and no obvious localizing source. Given bleeding into
   OP and possibly airways yesterday, there is concern for
   pneumonitis/recurrent aspiration pna. Sputum Cx re-sent. CXR improved

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old man with squamous cell carcinoma of the larynx who was admitted to the ICU for right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site. He underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery and was packed by ENT. The bleeding has been stabilized, and the patient is currently on ventilator support. The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and has completed a 10-day course of antibiotics. He also has chronic anemia, hyponatremia, and hypertension.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Bleeding from the tracheostomy site: The patient is at risk for further bleeding, especially if the packing is removed or if the bleeding is not controlled.
2. Pneumonitis/Recurrent Aspiration PNA: The patient's new leukocytosis and elevated WBC count may indicate a possible infection, which could lead to pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia.
3. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension needs to be controlled, especially with a systolic blood pressure of 120s, as per ENT's recommendation.
4. Anemia: The patient's anemia is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation, and it is essential to monitor his hemoglobin levels closely.
5. Hyponatremia: The patient's chronic hyponatremia may be exacerbated by hypovolemia or SIADH, and serum and urine osmolarities are pending to determine the cause.
6. COPD: Although the patient does not currently have symptoms, his COPD requires continued management, including home nebulizers.
7. DVT: The patient has a DVT, which needs to be closely monitored for signs of pulmonary embolism (PE) or hemodynamic instability.
8. Leukocytosis: The patient's leukocytosis may be a sign of infection, and further evaluation is necessary to determine the cause.
9. Aspiration PNA: The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia, and it is essential to continue aspiration precautions and tracheostomy care.

Plan:

1. Continue to monitor the patient's bleeding from the tracheostomy site and adjust his management accordingly.
2. Evaluate the patient's leukocytosis and determine the cause of the elevation.
3. Continue to manage the patient's hypertension, anemia, and hyponatremia.
4. Monitor the patient's DVT for signs of PE or hemodynamic instability.
5. Continue to manage the patient's COPD with home nebulizers.
6. Follow up on the patient's sputum culture and blood and urine cultures to determine the cause of the leukocytosis and any potential infections.
7. Consider adding antibiotics for coverage of potential infections.
8. Continue to monitor the patient's nutritional status and adjust his diet as necessary.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man admitted to the ICU with a chief complaint of hemoptysis and a history of laryngeal cancer. He has undergone coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleeding, tracheostomy, and PEG.

The patient has been experiencing bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which was initially stable upon arrival to the ICU but developed into slow and persistent bleeding around the trachea and into the posterior oropharynx. The bleeding was packed by ENT and subsequently embolized by a neurointerventional radiologist. The patient was unpacked on day 2 with resolution of the bleeding.

The patient has been mechanically ventilated for further airway protection in the setting of refractory bleeding around the tracheostomy site. He has been tolerating pressure support with no difficulty and may be able to drop the cuff on the tracheostomy tube and use a tracheal mask if not actively bleeding.

The patient has a right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) with no symptoms of pulmonary embolism or hemodynamic instability. He has an inferior vena cava (IVC) filter in place and is not an anticoagulation candidate given the recent bleeding.

The patient has leukocytosis with a new onset of events, which is concerning for pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia. The patient's sputum culture is pending, and he is being treated with Clindamycin for ENT coverage.

The patient has a history of aspiration pneumonia and has completed a 10-day course of Ceftaz and Vanco. He has a new right lower lobe infiltrate on chest X-ray and elevated white blood cell count.

The patient has laryngeal cancer complicated by recent right inferior thyroid artery bleeding and is likely to begin chemotherapy as an outpatient.

The patient has hypertension, which was hypertensive yesterday but is currently normotensive. He is taking home lisinopril 40 mg daily and may require additional antihypertensive medication.

The patient has anemia, which is stable from recent baseline values and is likely secondary to bleeding and inflammation. He has received 2 units of packed red blood cells.

The patient has hyponatremia, which appears to be hypovolemic but could also be related to SIADH. Serum and urine osmolalities are pending.

The patient has chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD) with no current complaints of shortness of breath or dyspnea.

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

1. Pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia: The patient's leukocytosis and new onset of events are concerning for pneumonitis or recurrent aspiration pneumonia.
2. Bleeding: The patient has a history of bleeding from the tracheostomy site, which could recur if not properly managed.
3. Deep vein thrombosis: The patient has a right lower extremity DVT, which could lead to pulmonary embolism if not properly managed.
4. Hypertension: The patient's hypertension could lead to complications such as cardiac failure, stroke, or renal failure if not properly managed.
5. Anemia: The patient's anemia could lead to complications such as fatigue, weakness, and decreased oxygen delivery to tissues if not properly managed.
6. Hyponatremia: The patient's hyponatremia could lead to complications such as seizures, coma, and death if not properly managed.
7. COPD exacerbation: The patient's COPD could exacerbate if not properly managed, leading to complications such as respiratory failure, pneumonia, and death.

Based on the patient's condition, it is recommended that he continue to receive close monitoring and management of his bleeding, anemia, hypertension, hyponatremia, and COPD. He should also receive antibiotics for ENT coverage and continue to receive Clindamycin for aspiration pneumonia.

Based on the patient's progress note, the following summary and potential medical complications can be identified:

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of squamous cell carcinoma in the larynx, who underwent tracheostomy and packing for bleeding after initial mapping and radiation therapy (XRT). He has undergone embolization and packing removal, with no rebleeding observed. The patient is currently tolerating pressure support ventilation (PSV) and has had a trial of tidal volume (TM) today. He is being treated for respiratory failure, hemoptysis, deep vein thrombosis (DVT), and laryngeal cancer.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure:
	* Pneumonia: The patient is at risk for developing pneumonia due to the tracheostomy and prolonged intubation.
	* Ventilator-associated pneumonia (VAP): The patient is at risk for developing VAP due to the prolonged use of the ventilator.
2. Hemoptysis:
	* Rebleeding: The patient is at risk for rebleeding from the tracheostomy site or other areas.
	* Aspiration: The patient is at risk for aspiration due to the inability to protect his airway.
3. DVT:
	* Pulmonary embolism (PE): The patient is at risk for developing a PE due to the DVT and immobility.
4. Laryngeal Cancer:
	* Recurrence: The patient is at risk for recurrence of the laryngeal cancer.
	* Spread to other areas: The patient is at risk for spread of the cancer to other areas of the body.
5. Nutritional Deficiencies:
	* Malnutrition: The patient is at risk for malnutrition due to the prolonged use of the ventilator and limited oral intake.
6. Infection:
	* Sepsis: The patient is at risk for developing sepsis due to the prolonged use of the ventilator and the risk of infection.

Overall, the patient is critically ill and requires close monitoring and management to prevent and treat potential complications.

Based on the provided progress note, the patient is a 67-year-old man who was admitted to the ICU for right lower extremity deep vein thrombosis (DVT) and significant bleeding from the tracheostomy site. He underwent coil embolization of the right inferior thyroid artery for hypopharyngeal bleeding and was previously mechanically ventilated. He was weaned off the ventilator and is now on a tracheostomy mask.

The patient's current vital signs are:

* Temperature: 36.7°C (98°F)
* Heart rate: 76 beats per minute (bpm)
* Blood pressure: 122/56 mmHg
* Respiratory rate: 11 inspirations per minute
* Oxygen saturation: 97%

The patient's laboratory results show:

* White blood cell count: 18.0 x 10^9/L
* Hematocrit: 27.8%
* Platelet count: 488 x 10^9/L
* Creatinine: 0.5 mg/dL
* Total CO2: 32 mmHg
* Glucose: 116 mg/dL
* Calcium: 8.6 mg/dL
* Magnesium: 2.0 mg/dL
* Phosphorus: 3.6 mg/dL

The patient's medical conditions include:

* Squamous cell carcinoma (SCC) of the larynx
* Right lower extremity DVT
* Hypopharyngeal bleed
* Tracheostomy and percutaneous endoscopic gastrostomy (PEG)
* Aspiration pneumonia (PNA) with methicillin-resistant Staphylococcus aureus (MRSA)
* Laryngeal cancer
* Hypertension
* Anemia
* Hyponatremia
* Chronic obstructive pulmonary disease (COPD)
* Previous cerebrovascular accident (CVA)

The patient's current medications include:

* Clindamycin for ENT coverage
* Ranitidine for stress ulcer prophylaxis
* Heparin sodium for DVT prophylaxis
* Lisinopril for hypertension
* Labetalol for hypertension (IV)
* Nutren Pulmonary for nutrition

The patient's plan includes:

* Continue XRT to head and neck for bleeding control
* Maintain active surveillance for bleeding
* No anticoagulation
* Start Clindamycin for ENT coverage
* Continue home nebs for COPD
* Monitor anemia and hyponatremia closely
* Consider adding beta-blocker as needed for hypertension

Potential medical complications that can arise include:

* Rebleeding from the tracheostomy site
* Development of pulmonary embolism (PE)
* Worsening of anemia and hyponatremia
* Increased risk of infection due to tracheostomy and PEG
* Development of respiratory failure
* Hypertensive crisis
* Increased risk of bleeding due to chemotherapy

The patient's code status is full code, and his disposition is ICU.

Summary:

The patient is a 67-year-old male with a history of squamous cell carcinoma (SCCA) in the larynx, who has undergone tracheostomy and packing for bleeding. He has had encouraging absence of bleeding following removal of packing. The patient is currently on invasive ventilation, tolerating positive pressure ventilation (PSV) and is undergoing trial of tracheostomy tube removal. He is receiving antibiotics and has had embolization and packing removal 2 days ago with no rebleed. The patient has a history of hemoptysis, DVT, and laryngeal cancer. He will need to discuss his wishes for surgery if he rebleeds, as he was sedated during a family meeting.

Potential Medical Complications:

1. Respiratory Failure: The patient is still on invasive ventilation, and there is a risk of respiratory failure if the tracheostomy tube is removed prematurely or if there is a sudden change in his respiratory status.
2. Hemoptysis: Although the patient has had encouraging absence of bleeding following removal of packing, there is still a risk of rebleeding, which could lead to respiratory distress and hypoxia.
3. DVT: The patient is at risk of developing DVT due to his immobility and the presence of a central venous catheter. This could lead to pulmonary embolism, which could be life-threatening.
4. Laryngeal Cancer: The patient's laryngeal cancer may progress and lead to further complications, such as airway obstruction or bleeding.
5. Infection: The patient is at risk of developing infections, particularly pneumonia, due to his prolonged hospitalization and the presence of a tracheostomy tube.
6. Gastrointestinal Bleeding: The patient's history of bleeding and the presence of a tracheostomy tube increase his risk of gastrointestinal bleeding.
7. Hypoglycemia: The patient's history of diabetes and the use of insulin and other medications increase his risk of hypoglycemia.
8. Hyperkalemia: The patient's history of kidney disease and the use of medications that increase potassium levels increase his risk of hyperkalemia.
9. Hypocalcemia: The patient's history of hypocalcemia and the use of medications that decrease calcium levels increase his risk of hypocalcemia.
10. Anemia: The patient's history of anemia and the use of medications that decrease red blood cell production increase his risk of anemia.

Overall, the patient is at risk of developing various medical complications, and close monitoring and management are necessary to prevent or treat these complications.
